description: 1575, from Late Latin ēlabōrātus (“worked out”), past participle of ēlabōrō (“to work out”), from ē- (“out, forth, fully”) + labor (“work, toil, exertion”). More at e-, labour.

adjectives.description: elaborate (comparative more elaborate, superlative most elaborate)

examples: After reading a long, elaborate description, I was impressed but no wiser.
I stared for hours at the elaborate pattern in the rug.

verbs.description: elaborate (third-person singular simple present elaborates, present participle elaborating, simple past and past participle elaborated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to develop in detail or complexity
examples: […]  by the time of the subsequent coronation, when the Prussian king put the crown on his own head in child-like belief of the obsolete doctrine called divine right, the untiring statesman had elaborated his scheme of reform.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) (sometimes followed by on or upon, and then the object of the preposition) to expand/enlarge in detail
examples: What do you mean you didn't come home last night? Would you care to elaborate?
Could you elaborate on the plot for your novel for me?
